top10_tweets_like: Have you ever needed to compare two complex R objects? The new waldo package makes it much easier. Learn more at https://t.co/9PAMLwyk1G #rstats https://t.co/suJ419utgF

If you've ever wondered exactly how Shiny's reactive graph works, I have new "Mastering Shiny" book chapter up: https://t.co/VnFLQdS1Xk #rstats. As always, your feedback is much appreciated! https://t.co/Ye6qLEgFVz

POSTDOC ALERT!

Are you a total #rstats nerd and love using your coding powers to help answer complex & interesting biology questions? 

Then this postdoc position in our SQuID group is just the thing for you! Highly collaborative, very fun group! Pls RT https://t.co/qnkFNbmrcT
The long-awaited visual editor for #rmarkdown files is finally available on the latest #RStudio Preview. #rstats https://t.co/o6bPQQ3Jvh
gert 1.0: simple git client for #rstats now on CRAN! So many new cool things! https://t.co/f5a37eWsvh. Blog post soon.

With all this #AcademicChatter going on about data cleaning and processing, I must admit I've never actually been taught *how* to clean data. Any good tutorials or checklists? I'm often afraid there are data cleaning steps I'm missing or overlooking  #RStats

I use run-length encoding a fair bit, and wrote {purler} in order to have some features not available in base::rle()

* 10x faster (using C code)
* Intuitive handling of NAs
* Result returned as a data.frame for tidy manipulation!

Now with hex!

https://t.co/kIc7DQmFHx

#RStats https://t.co/iaRTtBY1xP

You can use the %<>% operator (in the magrittr package) to update an object with a pipe. 

  a %<>% f %>% g

is the same as 

  a <- a %>% f %>% g 

https://t.co/2kEyvvieMb #rstats
